segments.text: Translation They had not seen each other for almost two weeks.
Two days after they arrived, the soldiers led by him were transferred to a remote, forgotten area for training in preparation for a secret operation that even she knew little about.
One day, the battalion commander offered her to join him for a short visit to the field.
After nearly three hours of travel, during which the Jeep bounced and rattled along a rough path, they arrived, and she happily got out.
Feeling the solid ground under her feet again, from afar she saw him emerge from a group of soldiers and approached them.
Only then did she realize how much she had missed him.
She watched his slow, slightly tired walk, noticing his wild, dusty curls, and now as he was close, also his red, kind, loving eyes.
They exchanged small, almost hidden smiles.
He greeted the battalion commander and thanked him for taking the trouble to visit.
She left them alone, approached the group of soldiers, and asked with a smile, can I get a cup of coffee here?
Within minutes, they brought her a small glass cup with coffee from a Fingin.
She sat cross-legged on the ground beside them.
Suddenly, she noticed an officer with the rank of captain, sitting in a crouch, somewhat to the side, leaning against something between a low tree and a bush.
He was older, with delicate features and all of dark skin.
She recognized him immediately, looked at him excitedly, and unable to stop herself, asked, Salah?
He gave her a surprised look.
He had no idea who she was or how she knew him.
Yes, he replied.
And who are you?
She got up, moved to sit close by his side, and almost in a whisper said just for his ear, I am Lucy's youngest daughter from the pink house.
She was ready to swear she saw tears well up in the eyes of the Bedouin tracker, who had long since crossed his youth.
But don't say anything.
I don't share my life with them.
They have enough of their own problems.
He reached out in excitement and held her hand like an adult to a child.
Still not saying a word.
Then whispered back to her.
I'm not ashamed to say, sometimes I really miss her.
She looked at him warmly.
She loved you very much, she said quietly.
Mom would tell dad that with all your tracking and combat skills, you have a gentle soul and almost mystical connection to the land.
I was a little girl, and those mornings when I would wake up and find you sleeping on the grass would ignite my imagination, like in stories.
She looked at him in excitement, not noticing the soldiers around them staring in wonder at the intimacy shared between them as they sat holding hands like two children.
In a moment, she traveled back to her childhood days, almost able to smell the aroma of quail roasting slowly in Lucy's kitchen, just waiting for the soldiers to wake up.
It was three o'clock in the morning.
The whole neighborhood was asleep.
It was still completely dark, with only the streetlight eliminating the sign, the pink house.
Two military jeeps stopped along the road, and from them slipped about ten soldiers, almost stealthily, taking a few steps and entering the vast garden.
They sprawled on the scattered deck chairs and the grass, placing their hands under their necks instead of pillows.
Readying for a morning sleep to replace the night spent on operational activities in the strip, Bess left unspoken.
On their way back, they hunted a few quail and rabbits, handing them to Salah, the chief tracker, to clean with years of expertise, placing the clean meat on a tarp on the jeep's edge.
Upon reaching the garden, Salah took the tarp with all its contents, opened the garden faucet, and thoroughly washed all the meat of any remnants.
Only then, when everything was completely clean, did he set it at Lucy's kitchen entrance, covering it with the tarp's other end before retreating to the grass to grab a few hours of sleep.
When the first light emerged, the pink house's garden looked surreal.
Soldiers scattered on the grass, sleeping soundly with the giant China Berry tree, casting its shadow over them.
At 6.30, when Lucy came to the kitchen, Fortuna approached her.
The soldiers who guard us came, brought the meat and are sleeping on the grass.
They'll probably wake up only in the afternoon, she reported.
Lucy smiled.
She was very happy about this group of soldiers from the elite unit arriving at her doorstep at the end of covert operations.
It was a very tense security year, and her heart was filled with joy knowing she could provide them with a few hours of rest.
The game dishes turned into delicacies by her hands and the sleep on the grass.
became a kind of ritual that year.
Sometimes when she looked at them, she thought they were so young.
Some even looked like kids.
Only the commander and Salok, the chief tracker, were a bit older.
Salok was, in her eyes, a unique man, slim, dark and tall, with delicate features and deep black eyes.
She liked him very much, and he treated her with great respect.
Each time he brought her a small gift, once a copper finjon, another time an engraved tray, and once he brought Yosef a kafia.
Each time he'd also invite them to visit his tribe in the north.
Come, we'll throw you a big party like you do for us.
And she'd always reply, one day we might really come, Salak.
And he would be pleased with her answer.
She said about cooking the meat in two large pots.
Fortuna helped her, peeling carrots, potatoes and onions, tossing them into the pot.
Then setting up a pot of rice with chopped onions and shredded carrot to give the rice a yellow color and aroma.
In the morning, as soon as she saw they'd arrived, she took out the sifted chickpeas from the container she stored them in and put a quantity of them to soak in hot water with a little baking soda.
Now she drained the water and set them to cook until they softened.

Gradually, over about two hours, the quail and rabbits turned into a soft roast steeped with vegetables that cooked together in the pot, filling the kitchen with a wonderful aroma that spread far and wide.
Around nine in the morning, the kitchen door suddenly opened and in the doorway stood Shoshana Damari, Lucy's friend.
The night before, she had performed for the residents on the large lawn in the center of Aphrodare and had stayed at their hotel.
She immediately noticed the early bustle in the kitchen.
This wasn't the first time she had encountered the group of soldiers sleeping on the grass.
Fortuna, she asked.
Are the chickpeas soft yet?
Maybe yes, maybe no, Fortuna replied.
She looked at Shoshana in admiration.
Nine in the morning, and she was already with her large earrings and her abundance of black curls, though without a drop of makeup.
But even so, one could not ignore her.
If that wasn't enough.
She wore one of her famous blouses with elastic at the top that can be pulled over the hands, creating a big neckline.
Shoshana checked if the chickpeas had softened, and when she decided they were ready, Fortuna poured out all the water, leaving only a bit at the bottom.
Shoshana took a large wooden spoon, poured in tahini, squeezed lemons, crushed garlic, added black pepper and salt, and began to mash the chickpeas.
Then only began to stir vigorously for long minutes until the mixture turned smooth and beautiful.
Only then did she take a spoonful from it, extended it to Fortuna, and asked, is it tasty?
Traybon, Fortuna said, and Shoshana laughed with her deep rolling laugh, infecting Lucy, who infected Fortuna, and all three stood and laughed.
The radio played in the background, and in perfect timing, Shoshana's voice came out, singing her song, Unknown Class.
Fortuna recognized that it was our singer and her chest swelled with pride.
Once overcoming her shyness, she asked Lucy, how is it that she is your friend, that you are from Russia and she is from Yemen?
Lucy told her it was since they worked together in the theater in Tel Aviv.
Besides, I'm also friends with you and you're from Morocco.
And she hugged her shoulders gently.
Fortuna was so touched that she put the kitchen towel over her eyes.
so that Lady Lucy wouldn't see that I have tears in my eyes.
Joseph arrived and immediately joined in.
He connected two tables on the outside porch, placed chairs around them, and held Lucy set them up beautifully with pictures of lemonade and a large salad on the side.
Towards noon, the soldiers' eyes opened.
They washed their faces with the garden faucets water and only then sat at the table.
Salich gently tapped on the kitchen door and asked Lucy if he could help with anything.
What a smell you've made for us.
It could drive one crazy.
He exclaimed.
You sit, Lucy replied, send me two soldiers to bring the trays with food.
And I have a surprise for you.
Only after everyone sat and the food trays were already on the table did Lucy emerge with Shoshana, each holding large bowls of hummus.
Today we have ala Shoshana Damari hummus too.
Lucy announced.
The soldiers were stunned.
They clapped their hands, not knowing what to do with themselves.
Even this time, they licked their fingers, as Lucy would say, and another secret mission ended.
Do you remember that time when Shoshana Damari made you hummus?
Leora woke from her memories.
Yes, Salich replied with a smile.
It was touching, but nothing was as touching as knowing that at the end of a Raider activity, we'd find ourselves pampered on the pink house's grass with Lucy's delicacies.
We really looked forward to it.
Dan raised his head for a moment and saw her from afar, sitting very close to Salich, leaning towards each other with inexplicable intimacy.
He straightened with a feeling of watchfulness, mixed with a little envy.
He had no idea why Leora was talking to the older Bedouin tracker with such closeness.
After all, he was called to reserve duty for this special operation, and there's no way she knew him.
As if sensing his gaze, she lifted her eyes to him with an excited and childish smile on her face.
He didn't exactly calm down, but he understood that this scenario would also enter her list of secrets, awaiting explanations that were yet to come.
They stayed there together for only a short while, and exchanged no more than two words, besides the warm gaze and the hand that held hers for a moment, as she climbed back into the jeep.
Along the way.
She asked the battalion commander when the activity was supposed to occur.
Sorry, he replied.
I can't say and the truth is, I don't know right now.
I only know we need to be ready.
We'll see.
They traveled in contemplative silence.
The battalion commander sank into thoughts, and it seemed to her that he was tired.
After all, they left the base early for the field, and he had been driving for hours.
She drifted into her thoughts about Dan, feeling how the few minutes she saw him stirred a great longing in her for his touch, to hear him talk to her, speak to her.
She so wanted to share with someone what she was feeling about this emotion growing between them, developing into something so profound
They hadn't even begun their journey, and already she missed him.
The road twisted through the primordial landscapes of the Judean Desert, which she loved so much.
She had so many memories from the short period Yosef lived there.
She sank into thoughts, not noticing the battalion commander entering the gas station on the way to Arad.
I need coffee," he declared.
She happily got out of the jeep.
She could also use a stretch and a cup of coffee.
As soon as they entered the café, she saw the battalion commander patting the back of a large man.
They hugged and cheered, and only when he turned did his face become visible to her.
She recognized him immediately and spontaneously smiled at him with a cheerful and illuminating smile.
He looked at her puzzled, not understanding what she wanted.
He had no idea who she was.
She approached him a few steps.
The last time I saw you, I was ten years old, she said joyfully.
I sat across from you in the dining room of Southern Command and watched you demolish an entire chicken.
He burst out laughing and hugged her.
I don't believe it.
You're Yosef's youngest.
How is he?
I haven't seen him in years.
The battalion commander watched their meeting in astonishment.
It's almost a reunion.
He smiled.
Avraham was my commander years ago.
Did you know he is now the director of the nature reserves authority?
They exchanged a few more words and parted.
greet your father warmly and also your beautiful mother.
The battalion commander's heart skipped a beat.
He looked at her carefully to see if she would correct him and tell him that her mother had passed away a few years earlier.
But she didn't say a word, presumably to not dampen his mood.
The battalion commander and Leora sat facing each other with their coffee cups.
She felt the need to explain the meaning of the meeting.
For a certain period, my father managed the hostels of Sodom, Masada, and Engeti.
It was during this time that Avraham Yafi was the southern command commander, and a close friendship developed between them.
Once when I visited my father, Avraham gave me a ride back to Ashkelon, to Mother, and along the way we stopped for lunch at the headquarters.
Again, silence between them.
Her and her secrets, he thought to himself, watching her staring with a half-smile, drifting into other realms, completely immersed in memories.
He said nothing and let her be.
She couldn't escape the nostalgia for that period, recalling how her dear father ended up in Sodom and Gomorrah.

Just before her tenth birthday, on a wet and wintry day, after rain had been pouring outside for hours, the entrance door suddenly opened with force, and at the door stood a large man with wild hair, shaking off the raindrops that clung to him, and half said, half announced, Hello, I'm Yehuda Almug.
I intend to stay with you for a long time because I have to finish writing my book about the Dead Sea region.
Like the regular guests, he soon became an integral part of the house.
He could be seen tucked away in various quiet corners, bent over his pages, writing incessantly as if knowing he had a task to complete.
Lissy would quietly approach, place a cup of tea with cookies before him, or a sandwich if he was hungrier.
And everyone tried to tiptoe around so as not to disturb him.
Yehuda Almug was a member of the Halitz movement, one of the heads of the labor battalion, and the personal assistant to Yosef Trumpledor.
He was a central figure in the Kiblitz-Muhad movement and a representative of the Potash company in Sodom before the state was established.
Even after the establishment of the Dead Sea Works, he continued to be involved in their activities and eventually became the first head of the Dead Sea Regional Council, Tamar.
He was among the founders of Einharud, moved to Tel-Yosif, and finally settled in Khvar-Giladi.
Although he spent most of his days in the Dead Sea area, his family remained in Khvar-Giladi.
His wife, Hava, would sometimes visit him and became friends with Lucy.
Almug, as Lucy called him, was a fascinating man with a no less fascinating history.
And gradually, through long conversations, sometimes late into the night, a close friendship developed between him and Yosef, despite the age difference between them.
Yosef was charmed by his stories about this virgin land and what else could be developed in it in the field of tourism.
even traveling with him once on a tour of the area.
Towards his departure, Almog turned to Yosef and offered him to take on the establishment and management of youth hostels in Sodom, Masada and Engedi.
These hostels were the beginning of tourism in this region.
Thus, as if called to service, excited about the thrilling change, Yosef temporarily left the pink house and moved to live at the Sodom Youth Hostel.
She, the little one, wasn't very enthusiastic about that man.
He wasn't particularly friendly, seeing a nuisance in the little girl wandering around Barefoot, a dog trailing her everywhere.
She was a bit angry that he took her dear father so far away.
Something about Yosef's timing in leaving for Sodom was apparently successful.
as it seemed that both he and Lucy needed a break from each other, and they almost rejoiced in ruling over their little kingdom separately.
But she, the child, missed him very much, and Almog would say that Yosef was sick with longing for her.
So,

Whenever the yearnings became too strong, that man would indeed reveal himself to be a person with a heart and send his driver to bring her the long way from Ashkelon to Sodom, to the lowest place on earth, to her dearest father.
The long journey with the endless twists was hard for her.
More than once she asked him to stop and would vomit her soul out.
but afterward she felt better, and they would continue on their way to that simple place, unbearably hot.
With only one advantage, her father was there.

Together with him, everyone tried to make her days their pleasant, taking her to bathe in the Dead Sea, not before warning her of scratches that would sting, to dip in the smelly sulfur springs at Neve Zohar, to enter the nearby cave and come out powdered white.
Naturally, after two or three days, it was already enough for her, and she wanted to return home.
Then she would become a hitchhiker for anyone Yosef knew going up north.
Almonk himself would occasionally step in, combining some business in the north with her return to Lucy.
They set off, the three of them.
The driver, Elmog, and she, while he told her, if you need to vomit, just say, don't be shy.
Trying to be amiable.
One time, she fell asleep, and as they climbed the twists from the Dead Sea toward Beersheva, a donkey suddenly ran across the road and slammed into them with a terrible bang.
She woke up frightened after being thrown from one side of the vehicle to the other and found him leaning over her to see if nothing had happened to her.
He, in fact, had a bleeding scratch on his forehead.
and she told him, you're bleeding.
He reassured her, gave her water to drink, and explained what had happened.
She didn't cry, just quietly looked at that man, who suddenly seemed gentle and kind.
The front of their vehicle was completely crushed, and on the road lay the dead donkey.
A minute hadn't passed, and another vehicle passing by recognized the sheriff of the Dead Sea, and picked them up.
They continued on their way.
When she got home, Lucy was agitated by the incident.
She talked to Yosef on the phone, and Leora heard her say to him, thank God it could have ended differently, can you believe it?
The child is just sad about the donkey left, dead on the road.
Two months later, after another visit to her father, she got into Avraham Yafi's jeep, the Southern Command General.
They headed up toward Beersheva to the command.
Avraham Yaffe was a big man.
She was fascinated by his size and the fact that he gave her an equally big smile, explaining they were going to have a good time.
First, they would have lunch at the command and then the driver would take her home to her mother.
After all, everyone was her father's friends and she felt very comfortable with them.
Throughout the journey, he told her funny stories, and for the first time, she didn't vomit at all.
When they reached the command, she noticed that every moment someone arrived and saluted him, and he saluted back.
She looked in puzzlement at this, and he smiled, explaining that this is how they say hello in the military to commanders.
Today you're my commander, he said, saluting her, smiling his warm smile.
She laughed and saluted back as she had seen.
And then they sat down to eat.
What can be said about that meal?
All her life she will remember it.
The big man sat and ate an entire chicken, so she later told Lucy.
She hardly ate.
She sat and watched him in complete admiration, demolishing drumstick after drumstick, thigh after thigh, seasoned with potatoes and drinks that were brought to him.
Only then did he raise his head and see her staring at him.
You ate the whole chicken," she said to him in awe.
He laughed loudly.
It's not because I was so hungry.
It's because I'm so big.
Shortly afterward, Yosef returned to their pink house and she was so happy.
Only much later did she understand that it was related to Lucy falling ill for the first time.
She raised her eyes and saw the battalion commander staring straight ahead at the road before them.
In her heart, she thanked him for leaving her to herself and her memories.
